caseTitle: COMMISSIONER OF POLICE VERSUS DIKO PIM
summary: The High Court of the Ashanti Judicial Division in Ghana considered whether the Ejisu Stool Property (No.2) Order, 1958, made under the Statute Law Amendment (No.2) Act, 1957, had legal force before its publication in the Gazette. The order, dated September 12, 1958, but published on September 20, authorized Nana Kofi Atta to seize stool property and eject occupants. Diko Pim and another were charged with obstructing this action on September 12. The Magistrate discharged them, ruling the order unenforceable before publication. The Attorney-General referred the case to the Supreme Court via case stated. The court held that the order constituted subsidiary legislation with legislative effect, not a mere executive act, and thus required publication in the Gazette to have legal force under the Interpretation Act, 1957. It further ruled that no offence was created by breaching the order, as the statute did not criminalize such conduct directly. Therefore, the appeal was dismissed.
rationaleHighlights: An order made under statutory authority is part of 'Act of Parliament' under s. 3(1) of the Interpretation Act, 1957
Section 5 of the Interpretation Act requires publication in the Gazette for an Act or order to take effect unless otherwise provided
Recital of date of making does not constitute provision for prior operation
To determine if an order is legislative or administrative, examine its effect and necessity for publication
Orders with far-reaching legal consequences are subsidiary legislation
No offence was created by the Act for breach of the order
Appeal dismissed because charge did not state a known offence
